The morning mist clung to the hospital corridors like a shroud, filtering through the tall windows of St. Margaret's General Hospital in ways that made even the most seasoned staff members uneasy. Nurse Patricia Williams had worked the night shift for seventeen years, but something about this particular dawn felt different—heavier, more ominous than usual. She couldn't shake the feeling that someone was watching her as she made her rounds through the cardiac wing.

Detective Inspector Maria Bourazopoulou laced up her running shoes in the cramped locker room of Salisbury Police Station, her mind already racing through the case files that had been piling up on her desk. At thirty-four, she had earned a reputation as one of the most tenacious investigators in Wiltshire, partly due to her ability to think clearly during her early morning runs through the ancient streets of Salisbury. The rhythmic pounding of her feet against pavement had a way of organizing her thoughts, of revealing connections that others might miss.

But today would be different. Today would mark the beginning of a case that would haunt her for years to come.

The call came in at 6:47 AM, just as Maria was finishing her usual five-mile circuit around the cathedral. Her mobile buzzed insistently against her hip, the screen displaying the number she'd memorized long ago—dispatch.

"Bourazopoulou here," she answered, still breathing hard from her run.

"Ma'am, we've got a situation at St. Margaret's. You need to get down here immediately. It's... well, it's unlike anything we've seen before."

Maria's pulse quickened, though not from the exercise. In her twelve years on the force, she'd learned to read the subtle inflections in her colleagues' voices. This wasn't routine. This was something that would stick with them all.

Twenty minutes later, she stood in the doorway of a patient room on the third floor, staring at what could only be described as a scene from a fever dream. Nurse Patricia Williams lay unconscious on the hospital bed, her uniform stained with tears from what appeared to have been uncontrollable laughter. But it was her skin that made Maria's stomach turn—every inch of exposed flesh had been painted a garish shade of orange, applied with meticulous care and artistic precision.

"She's alive," said Dr. James Henley, the attending physician who'd discovered Patricia during morning rounds. "Physically unharmed, but completely traumatized. She keeps mumbling about someone tickling her, about not being able to breathe from laughing so hard."

Maria pulled on latex gloves and approached the bed carefully. Patricia's eyes were open but unfocused, staring at something only she could see. Orange paint covered her arms, face, and neck—anywhere the perpetrator could reach without removing her clothing. The application was too even, too deliberate to be random violence.

"Has she said anything coherent?" Maria asked, crouching beside the bed.

Dr. Henley shook his head. "Only fragments. Something about a woman named Betty, and..." He paused, looking uncomfortable. "She keeps repeating slurs. Horrible language about gay people. But Patricia's never spoken that way before—everyone here will tell you she's one of the most accepting people you could meet."

The pieces began forming a puzzle in Maria's mind, though the picture they created made little sense. She'd seen psychological torture before, but never anything quite like this. The orange paint suggested premeditation, planning. The tickling indicated a desire to cause distress without permanent physical harm. But the homophobic element added a layer of complexity that troubled her deeply.

"I'll need to speak with her as soon as she's able," Maria said, standing and surveying the room for any clues the perpetrator might have left behind. "Has anyone checked the security footage?"

"That's the strange thing," Dr. Henley replied. "The cameras on this floor malfunctioned between 3 AM and 5 AM. Complete blackout. Maintenance is looking into it, but they say it appears someone knew exactly which wires to cut."

Maria felt the familiar tingle of recognition that came with confronting a worthy adversary. This wasn't random—it was planned, executed with precision, and designed to send a message. But what message, and to whom?

As she examined the room more closely, Maria noticed something that the medical staff had missed. On the window sill, barely visible against the white paint, someone had left a small symbol drawn in the same orange paint used on Patricia. It looked like a crude flower, or perhaps a sun with irregular rays extending outward.

"Doctor, did Patricia mention anything about her personal life recently? Any conflicts, relationship issues, anything that might make her a target?"

Dr. Henley considered the question carefully. "Well, she did mention that her daughter came out to her a few months ago. Patricia was over the moon about it—said she was proud of her daughter's courage. She even started volunteering with some LGBTQ+ support groups in her spare time."

The connection crystallized in Maria's mind like ice forming on a window. This wasn't random violence—it was targeted specifically because of Patricia's support for her gay daughter. Someone had chosen her precisely because she represented acceptance and love in the face of hatred.

But who was Betty?

Over the next three hours, Maria interviewed every member of the hospital staff who'd been on duty during the night shift. None of them had seen anything unusual, heard any disturbances, or noticed strangers in the building. It was as if the perpetrator had materialized from thin air, committed her bizarre crime, and vanished just as mysteriously.

Patricia finally became coherent enough to speak around noon, though her account of the attack was fragmented and terrifying.

"She was already in my room when I came in to check on Mr. Henderson," Patricia whispered, her voice hoarse from hours of involuntary laughter. "Just standing there in the shadows like she belonged. I asked if she needed help, if she was lost, and she smiled at me. Such a cold smile."

"What did she look like?" Maria asked gently, her notebook ready.

"Average height, maybe mid-thirties. Brown hair, nothing distinctive about her appearance. But her eyes..." Patricia shuddered. "Her eyes were full of hate. She asked me if I knew what I was doing to society, supporting degenerates and perverts. I told her she was wrong, that love was love, and that's when she grabbed me."

Patricia's account of the attack itself was almost too bizarre to believe. Betty had produced a small bottle of what appeared to be chloroform, but instead of rendering Patricia unconscious, it had only made her weak and unable to resist. Then came the tickling—methodical, relentless, designed to cause maximum psychological distress while leaving no permanent physical damage.

"She kept talking while she did it," Patricia continued, tears streaming down her cheeks. "Saying horrible things about gay people, about how I was corrupting society by accepting my daughter. The painting came last, after I was too exhausted to fight back. She said I looked better in orange, that it was the color of warning signs."

Maria felt anger rising in her chest, but she forced herself to remain professional. "Patricia, did she mention her last name, or anything that might help us identify her?"

"Betty Morrison," Patricia said without hesitation. "She introduced herself like we were meeting at a tea party. Said I should remember her name because I'd be seeing her again."

The name meant nothing to Maria, but she made a mental note to run it through every database available. As she prepared to leave the hospital, her phone buzzed with another call from dispatch.

"Ma'am, we've got another one."The second crime scene was located in a modest terraced house on Fisherton Street, just fifteen minutes from St. Margaret's Hospital. Maria arrived to find the familiar chaos of a fresh investigation—uniformed officers securing the perimeter, forensics teams preparing their equipment, and the inevitable cluster of curious neighbors gathering despite the afternoon drizzle that had begun to fall across Salisbury.

Sergeant Paul Hendricks met her at the front door, his usually composed demeanor betrayed by the tight lines around his eyes. In the eight years they'd worked together, Maria had learned to read Paul's expressions like a barometer for the severity of whatever awaited her inside. Today, that barometer was pointing toward storm conditions.

"Victim is Michael Chen, twenty-eight years old, works as a graphic designer from home," Paul began, consulting his notebook. "His partner, David Walsh, found him when he came back from a business trip about an hour ago. Same MO as the hospital—orange paint, evidence of prolonged tickling, and psychological trauma. But this one's worse, Maria. Much worse."

They climbed the narrow staircase to the second floor, where the smell of paint fumes mixed unpleasantly with something else—fear, perhaps, or the lingering presence of cruelty. The bedroom door stood open, revealing a scene that made Maria's professional composure waver for just a moment. Michael Chen sat on the edge of his bed, wrapped in a clean bathrobe that someone had draped around his shoulders, but his face and arms still bore the telltale orange staining. Unlike Patricia Williams, however, Michael was conscious and articulate, though his hands shook as he attempted to light a cigarette.

"Mr. Chen," Maria said gently, settling into a chair that Paul had positioned near the bed. "I'm Detective Inspector Bourazopoulou. I know this is difficult, but I need to ask you some questions about what happened here."

Michael looked up at her with eyes that seemed decades older than his twenty-eight years. The orange paint had been applied with the same meticulous care as at the hospital—every visible inch of skin covered, but no damage to clothing or personal belongings. It was a signature, Maria realized, a calling card that spoke to the perpetrator's need for recognition and control.

"She knew everything about me," Michael said, his voice barely above a whisper. "Things that aren't public, things that only David and I know about our relationship. She talked about our anniversary dinner last month, about the argument we had over adopting a dog, about my mother's reaction when I came out to her three years ago. How could she know all of that?"

The implications sent a chill through Maria that had nothing to do with the October weather. This wasn't opportunistic violence—it was stalking, research, planning that must have taken weeks or months to execute. Betty Morrison, if that was even her real name, had chosen her victims carefully and studied them with the dedication of a scholar.

"Did she introduce herself the same way as she did to Patricia Williams?" Maria asked, though she suspected she already knew the answer.

Michael nodded, taking a shaky drag from his cigarette. "Betty Morrison, like we were old friends meeting for coffee. She was already here when I woke up this morning, sitting in that chair you're in now, just watching me sleep. I thought I was dreaming at first, or maybe having a nightmare. But when I tried to move, I realized she'd tied my hands to the bedframe while I slept."

The violation was profound—not just the physical restraint, but the knowledge that someone had been in his most private space, watching him in his most vulnerable state. Maria had seen victims of home invasion before, and she recognized the particular type of trauma that came from having one's sanctuary transformed into a crime scene.

"The tickling went on for hours," Michael continued, his voice growing stronger as he spoke, as if telling the story was helping him process the experience. "She had tools—feathers, brushes, even an electric toothbrush. But it was the talking that was worst. The things she said about David and me, about gay people in general. She had this theory that homosexuality was a disease that could be cured through what she called 'corrective discomfort.'"

Maria exchanged glances with Paul, who was taking detailed notes. They'd both encountered hate crimes before, but this felt different—more organized, more ideologically driven than the usual drunken violence or opportunistic harassment that comprised most anti-LGBTQ+ incidents in their jurisdiction.

"Michael, did she mention anything about other people she planned to visit? Any indication that this was part of a larger plan?"

"She talked about cleaning up the neighborhood," Michael replied, stubbing out his cigarette with more force than necessary. "Said there were too many people like me and David corrupting the traditional values of Salisbury. She mentioned something about a list, about working her way through names she'd collected over the past year."

The word 'list' struck Maria like a physical blow. A serial offender with a predetermined set of targets was every detective's nightmare—it meant more victims, escalation, and the constant pressure of trying to predict the unpredictable. But it also meant patterns, and patterns could be analyzed, understood, and ultimately used to catch the perpetrator.

"Did she give you any indication of how she chose you specifically?" Maria pressed. "Anything that might help us understand her selection criteria?"

Michael was quiet for a long moment, staring at his paint-stained hands. When he finally spoke, his voice carried a weight that suggested he'd been wrestling with the same question since the attack ended.

"She knew about the pride flag we hung in our front window during Pride Month," he said slowly. "She knew about David's work with the youth LGBTQ+ center. She even knew that we'd been planning to get married next summer, though we've only told our closest friends and family. It's like she's been watching us, cataloging everything we do that might identify us as gay."

The methodical nature of the surveillance was becoming clear, and it painted a picture of someone with significant time, resources, and dedication to her cause. Maria made a mental note to have the tech team examine Michael and David's social media accounts, their online presence, and any digital footprints that might have provided Betty Morrison with her intelligence.

"There's something else," Michael added, hesitating as if he wasn't sure whether to continue. "She took pictures. Not during the attack itself, but afterward, when I was too exhausted to resist. She said they were for her collection, to document her work. She was very proud of the paint job—kept talking about it like it was art."

The revelation added another disturbing dimension to the crimes. Photography suggested trophy-taking behavior, a desire to relive the attacks or possibly to share them with others who might share her ideology. It also raised the possibility that Betty Morrison wasn't working alone, that she might be part of a larger group or network of like-minded individuals.

As Maria prepared to conclude the interview, David Walsh appeared in the doorway, still wearing his business suit from his interrupted trip. He was a tall man with kind eyes that were currently red with tears and exhaustion, and his first instinct was clearly to protect his partner rather than assist with the investigation.

"Has he told you everything you need?" David asked, moving to sit beside Michael on the bed and wrapping an arm around his shoulders. "He's been through enough for one day."

Maria nodded, recognizing the signs of a couple that had been together long enough to communicate without words. "Just one more question, if you don't mind. Michael, did Betty Morrison leave any kind of calling card or symbol behind? Anything that might be significant to her personally?"

Michael brightened slightly, as if remembering something important. "On the mirror in our bathroom—she drew something in the orange paint before she left. It looked like a flower, but wrong somehow. Twisted."

Paul was already moving toward the ensuite bathroom, and his sharp intake of breath confirmed what Maria had suspected. The same crude symbol from Patricia Williams' hospital room was there, painted on the mirror in orange strokes that were confident and practiced. Betty Morrison wanted them to know she was responsible, wanted them to understand that this was just the beginning.

As they prepared to leave the Chen-Walsh residence, Maria's mind was already working through the connections and implications. Two victims, both connected to the LGBTQ+ community through personal relationships or activism. Both attacks involving orange paint applied with artistic precision. Both victims forced to endure hours of psychological torture designed to humiliate and terrify rather than cause permanent physical harm. And both left with the same symbol, the same signature that proclaimed Betty Morrison's twisted brand of ideological warfare.

The afternoon was darkening into evening by the time Maria returned to Salisbury Police Station, her notebook filled with details that painted an increasingly disturbing picture of their perpetrator. Betty Morrison was organized, patient, and driven by a hatred so profound that it had motivated her to develop an entirely new form of hate crime—one that maximized psychological impact while minimizing legal consequences.**Chapter 2: The Orange Canvas**

Maria's desk at Salisbury Police Station had become a sprawling canvas of crime scene photographs, witness statements, and forensic reports that seemed to multiply with each passing hour. The fluorescent lights overhead cast harsh shadows across the images of orange-painted skin, creating an almost surreal gallery that would have been artistic if not for the underlying violence it represented. She had been staring at the same photograph for ten minutes—a close-up of the crude flower symbol left at both crime scenes—when Detective Constable Sarah Lynch knocked on her office door frame.

Sarah was twenty-six years old and relatively new to the detective division, but she possessed an analytical mind that complemented Maria's more intuitive approach to investigation. Her background in digital forensics had already proven invaluable in several recent cases, and Maria had specifically requested her assistance with what was rapidly becoming known around the station as the Orange Paint Case. The younger detective carried a steaming cup of coffee in one hand and a thick manila folder in the other, her expression suggesting she had discovered something significant.

"I've been running searches on Betty Morrison all afternoon," Sarah began, settling into the chair across from Maria's desk and opening her folder with the careful precision of someone who had spent hours organizing information. "The name appears in seventeen different databases across the UK, but none of the individuals match our perpetrator's description or demographic profile. Three of them are deceased, eight are over sixty years old, four are currently incarcerated, and two have solid alibis for both attack timeframes. I'm starting to think Betty Morrison might not be her real name."

Maria looked up from the photograph, unsurprised by Sarah's findings but disappointed nonetheless. Experienced criminals often used aliases, particularly when their crimes were ideologically motivated and planned well in advance. The fact that Betty Morrison had introduced herself so formally to both victims suggested either supreme confidence in her ability to evade capture or a deliberate attempt to mislead the investigation from the very beginning.

"What about the orange paint itself?" Maria asked, leaning back in her chair and rubbing her temples where a headache had been building for the past two hours. "Have forensics been able to tell us anything about the brand, the composition, where it might have been purchased?"

Sarah's expression brightened slightly as she flipped through several pages in her folder, clearly pleased to have some concrete information to share. "That's where we might have caught a break. The paint is a specialized theatrical makeup called 'Sunset Orange' manufactured by a company called Dramatic Arts Supply in London. It's not the kind of thing you'd find at your average hardware store or pharmacy. According to the manufacturer, it's primarily sold to theater companies, film studios, and specialty costume shops. They've only had twelve orders for this specific color in the past six months, and most of those were bulk purchases by established entertainment companies."

The specificity of the paint choice struck Maria as significant, another indication that Betty Morrison's crimes were carefully planned rather than impulsive acts of violence. The selection of theatrical makeup also suggested someone with knowledge of performance arts, costume design, or possibly even experience in theater production. It was the kind of detail that could narrow their search parameters considerably, assuming they could track down the specific purchase records and connect them to their perpetrator.

"I want you to contact every retailer that sells this paint within a hundred-mile radius of Salisbury," Maria instructed, making notes on a legal pad that was already covered with her handwriting from earlier in the day. "Get purchase records, security camera footage if it's still available, and descriptions of any customers who bought this specific color in the past six months. Also, reach out to local theater groups, costume rental companies, and art schools. Someone who knows about theatrical makeup might be involved in those communities."

Sarah nodded, scribbling additional notes in her own notebook before continuing with her report. "There's something else that might be relevant. I've been analyzing the social media presence of both victims, looking for common connections or shared online activities that might have brought them to our perpetrator's attention. Patricia Williams joined a Facebook group called 'Supportive Parents of LGBTQ+ Children' three months ago, right around the time her daughter came out. She's been quite active in the group, sharing articles about acceptance and offering encouragement to other parents who are struggling with their children's sexual orientation."

The online component added another layer to Betty Morrison's surveillance capabilities, and it suggested she was technologically sophisticated enough to monitor social media for potential targets. Maria had seen similar patterns in stalking cases, where perpetrators used online platforms to gather intelligence about their victims' daily routines, relationships, and vulnerabilities. The fact that Patricia Williams had been targeted so soon after joining a support group indicated that Betty Morrison was actively monitoring LGBTQ+ related online communities.

"What about Michael Chen and David Walsh?" Maria asked, though she suspected she already knew what Sarah had discovered during her digital investigation.

"Even more extensive online presence," Sarah replied, pulling out several printed screenshots from social media profiles. "David Walsh runs a blog called 'Love is Love in Salisbury' where he writes about LGBTQ+ issues in our community. He's been documenting their relationship for almost two years, including photos of their home, details about their daily routines, and their involvement with local pride events. Michael Chen is less active online, but he's tagged in most of David's posts and photos. Anyone following the blog would have a comprehensive understanding of their lives, their schedules, and their relationship dynamics."

The extent of the victims' online exposure was troubling, though Maria recognized that she couldn't fault them for living openly and celebrating their relationships. The problem wasn't their visibility—it was Betty Morrison's decision to use that visibility as a targeting mechanism for hate crimes. Still, understanding how the perpetrator selected her victims provided valuable insight into her methodology and might help predict future attacks.

Maria's contemplation was interrupted by a sharp knock on her office door, followed immediately by the appearance of Chief Inspector Robert Hawthorne. Hawthorne was a career policeman in his late fifties, known throughout the station for his direct communication style and his particular concern for crimes that might attract media attention or public controversy. His presence in Maria's office, combined with the grim expression on his weathered face, suggested that the Orange Paint Case had already attracted the kind of attention that made senior administrators nervous.

"Maria, I need to speak with you about these paint attacks," Hawthorne began without preamble, closing the office door behind him and lowering his voice to the tone he reserved for sensitive discussions. "I've just gotten off the phone with the Chief Constable, and there's concern that we might be dealing with something more organized than individual hate crimes. The Home Office has been monitoring online chatter in extremist communities, and there are indications that anti-LGBTQ+ groups have been discussing new tactics for what they call 'corrective intervention' without crossing the line into serious criminal charges."

The implications of organized hate group involvement sent a chill through Maria that had nothing to do with the October weather outside her office windows. Individual criminals, no matter how dedicated or methodical, operated within predictable parameters and could usually be caught through traditional investigative techniques. But organized groups possessed resources, networks, and ideological support systems that made them exponentially more dangerous and difficult to apprehend.

"Are we talking about established groups like Britain First or the English Defence League?" Maria asked, though she hoped the answer would be negative. Those organizations had legal teams, media connections, and political supporters that complicated law enforcement efforts significantly.

"Nothing that prominent," Hawthorne replied, settling into the remaining chair in Maria's cramped office. "According to our intelligence contacts, there are smaller, more radical splinter groups that have been experimenting with psychological harassment techniques designed to terrorize LGBTQ+ individuals while staying just below the threshold of charges that would result in serious prison time. The use of theatrical paint, the emphasis on humiliation over physical harm, the careful documentation through photography—it all fits the profile of organized hate crime activity."

Sarah had been listening to the conversation with growing alarm, and Maria could see the younger detective processing the implications of what they were discussing. Moving from a single perpetrator case to an organized hate group investigation would require additional resources, specialized training, and coordination with national intelligence agencies that operated far above their normal jurisdictional level.

"What kind of support can we expect from London if this turns out to be group activity?" Maria asked, already dreading the answer. Metropolitan Police resources were stretched thin across numerous terrorism and organized crime investigations, and a relatively new hate group operating in Wiltshire might not rank high on their priority list.

"That depends on how quickly we can establish concrete connections between our local incidents and broader national patterns," Hawthorne replied diplomatically, which Maria recognized as bureaucratic language for 'you're on your own unless this becomes a major crisis.' "For now, we're expected to handle this as a local investigation while sharing intelligence with relevant national agencies. But Maria, if there are more attacks, if this escalates beyond what we've seen so far, we'll need to be prepared to hand this over to counterterrorism specialists."

The meeting concluded with Maria feeling the familiar weight of a case that was growing beyond her initial expectations, but also with a renewed sense of purpose that came from understanding the broader implications of Betty Morrison's crimes. As Sarah gathered her files and prepared to continue her research into paint suppliers and online communities, Maria found herself staring once again at the crime scene photographs spread across her desk.

The orange paint that had seemed like a bizarre quirk of an individual perpetrator now took on more sinister connotations as the possible signature of an organized movement. The meticulous application, the artistic precision, the careful documentation through photography—all of it suggested a level of coordination and planning that went beyond personal hatred and entered the realm of political terrorism. Betty Morrison, whether that was her real name or not, might not be working alone after all.

Evening shadows were lengthening across Salisbury by the time Maria finally left the police station, her mind churning with questions that seemed to multiply faster than she could find answers. The drive through the city center took her past St. Margaret's Hospital, where Patricia Williams was still recovering from her traumatic encounter, and then through the residential neighborhoods where Michael Chen and David Walsh were trying to rebuild their sense of security in their own home.The ancient cathedral spire pierced the darkening sky like a stone needle, its Gothic silhouette a reminder of Salisbury's deep historical roots and enduring traditions. As Maria drove slowly through the narrow streets that had witnessed nearly a thousand years of human drama, she couldn't help but reflect on how crimes like Betty Morrison's represented a corruption of the very community values that had allowed this city to thrive for so many centuries. The juxtaposition between Salisbury's reputation as a place of tolerance and cultural heritage and the reality of organized hate crimes occurring within its boundaries felt like a personal affront to everything she had sworn to protect as a police officer.

Her mobile phone buzzed insistently from the passenger seat, displaying Sarah's number on the caller identification screen. Maria pulled into a parking space near the cathedral close and answered the call, expecting an update on the paint supplier investigation or perhaps additional information about the victims' online activities. Instead, Sarah's voice carried an urgency that made Maria's pulse quicken with the familiar anticipation that came with significant developments in active investigations.

"Maria, you need to get back to the station immediately," Sarah said, her words coming in a rush that suggested she had been running or was experiencing the kind of adrenaline surge that accompanied major breakthroughs. "We've got another one, but this time it's different. This time she didn't get away clean, and we might actually have some physical evidence that could lead us directly to Betty Morrison's real identity."

The drive back to Salisbury Police Station took less than five minutes, but Maria's mind covered considerably more ground as she considered the implications of Sarah's cryptic statement. Physical evidence in the previous two attacks had been minimal—some fiber traces that could have come from any number of common clothing items, fingerprints that had yielded no matches in existing databases, and the orange paint samples that had proven useful for understanding the perpetrator's methodology but hadn't provided leads to her identity. The possibility that Betty Morrison had made a mistake, left something behind that could be traced back to her real-world identity, represented the kind of investigative breakthrough that could transform the entire case.

The police station's main entrance was busier than usual for evening hours, with several unmarked cars parked in spaces normally reserved for administrative staff and the kind of focused activity that indicated a major incident was in progress. Maria recognized the vehicles of senior investigators from other divisions, suggesting that word of the Orange Paint Case had spread throughout the department and was attracting attention from supervisors who normally focused on different types of criminal activity. As she pushed through the main doors, the desk sergeant nodded toward the interview rooms on the second floor, confirming that whatever Sarah had discovered was significant enough to warrant immediate attention from multiple departments.

Sarah was waiting in Interview Room B, accompanied by Detective Inspector James Morrison from the Sexual Crimes Unit and two uniformed constables whom Maria didn't immediately recognize. The presence of Morrison, despite the coincidental surname, suggested that the nature of the latest attack had crossed jurisdictional boundaries into territory that required specialized expertise in crimes involving sexual violence or psychological trauma. The arrangement of personnel around the interview table indicated they were preparing to speak with a witness or victim who might require sensitive handling due to the nature of their experience.

"Before you go in there," Sarah said, intercepting Maria in the corridor outside the interview room, "you need to understand what we're dealing with. The victim this time is Rebecca Torres, twenty-three years old, works as a library assistant at Salisbury University. She was attacked in her apartment around four o'clock this afternoon, but unlike Patricia Williams and Michael Chen, she managed to fight back effectively. Betty Morrison left blood behind, skin tissue under Rebecca's fingernails, and possibly hair fibers that could provide DNA evidence for the first time in this investigation."

The prospect of DNA evidence represented a quantum leap forward in their ability to identify and apprehend Betty Morrison, assuming the biological samples were sufficient for laboratory analysis and comparison with existing genetic databases. Maria felt the familiar surge of optimism that came with concrete leads, but she tempered her enthusiasm with the recognition that DNA evidence was only useful if it matched existing records or if they could obtain comparison samples from potential suspects. Still, the physical evidence would provide irrefutable proof of Betty Morrison's involvement in the attacks and could be crucial for prosecution even if it didn't immediately lead to her identification.

"What's Rebecca's condition?" Maria asked, preparing herself mentally for another encounter with a traumatized victim who had experienced Betty Morrison's particular brand of ideological violence. "Is she able to provide a coherent account of the attack, or are we dealing with the same kind of psychological fragmentation we saw with the previous victims?"

Sarah's expression brightened slightly, suggesting that Rebecca Torres might prove to be a more reliable witness than either Patricia Williams or Michael Chen had been immediately following their respective attacks. "She's shaken, obviously, but she's coherent and articulate. More importantly, she's angry rather than traumatized, which seems to have helped her process the experience more effectively. She's been asking when she can give her statement and whether we think we can catch this woman based on what happened today."

The difference in victim response patterns was significant, both for the investigation and for Rebecca's personal recovery from the attack. Victims who processed traumatic experiences through anger rather than fear often provided more detailed and accurate accounts of criminal incidents, partly because their emotional response motivated them to assist with apprehension efforts rather than simply trying to forget what had happened to them. Rebecca's combative attitude also suggested that Betty Morrison might have encountered unexpected resistance for the first time, potentially disrupting her usual methodology and causing her to make the kinds of mistakes that left physical evidence behind.

Maria entered the interview room to find Rebecca Torres sitting upright in her chair with the kind of posture that suggested determination rather than defeat. She was a petite woman with dark hair and intelligent eyes that tracked Maria's movement with the alertness of someone who had recently been forced to defend herself against an attacker. Her hands bore visible scratches and bruises that corroborated Sarah's account of physical resistance, and there were traces of orange paint on her clothing that indicated Betty Morrison had at least partially succeeded in applying her signature marking despite the victim's efforts to prevent it.

"Ms. Torres," Maria began, settling into the chair across the interview table and opening her notebook to a fresh page, "I'm Detective Inspector Bourazopoulou. I understand you've been through a terrible experience today, and I want you to know that we're taking this case very seriously. We believe your attacker is responsible for at least two other similar incidents in Salisbury over the past week, and any information you can provide might help us prevent future attacks on other members of our community."

Rebecca's response was immediate and forceful, delivered with the kind of clarity that suggested she had been thinking about this conversation since the attack ended several hours earlier. "She knew everything about me, just like she knew about the others, didn't she? My girlfriend Emma's work schedule, my volunteer activities with the university's LGBTQ+ society, even the fact that we've been planning to move in together next month. She had photographs of our apartment building, pictures of Emma and me together that she must have taken from across the street with a telephoto lens. This wasn't random—she's been stalking me for weeks, maybe months."

The confirmation of extended surveillance activities reinforced Maria's growing understanding of Betty Morrison as an organized, methodical predator who invested significant time and resources in selecting and researching her victims. The mention of photographs was particularly troubling, as it suggested a level of dedication to the stalking process that went beyond casual observation and entered the realm of professional surveillance techniques. The fact that Betty Morrison had been documenting her targets' daily routines and relationships also raised questions about whether she was working alone or reporting her intelligence gathering activities to other members of an organized group.

"Can you describe the attack itself?" Maria asked, recognizing that Rebecca's apparent emotional stability might not last indefinitely and wanting to capture as much detail as possible while the victim was still able to provide coherent testimony. "Start from the beginning—how did she gain access to your apartment, what did she say to you, and what happened during the physical confrontation that allowed you to fight back successfully?"

Rebecca took a deep breath, clearly marshaling her thoughts and preparing to relive an experience that had undoubtedly been terrifying despite her current composed demeanor. "I came home from work around three-thirty, same as always. I live in a ground-floor flat with a separate entrance, and I always lock the door behind me immediately because the neighborhood can be dodgy sometimes. But when I went into my bedroom to change clothes, she was already there, sitting in my reading chair like she owned the place. She must have broken in earlier in the day and just waited for me to come home."

The patience required for that kind of ambush strategy again demonstrated Betty Morrison's methodical approach to her crimes, but it also suggested a level of confidence in her ability to control situations that might have contributed to her making mistakes during the encounter with Rebecca. Perpetrators who became overconfident in their methods sometimes failed to adapt when victims responded differently than expected, leading to the kinds of tactical errors that left physical evidence behind or provided opportunities for escape and resistance.

"She introduced herself the same way she did with the others," Rebecca continued, her voice growing stronger as she spoke, as if telling the story was helping her process the experience psychologically. The morning mist clung to the hospital corridors like a shroud, filtering through the tall windows of St. Margaret's General Hospital in ways that made even the most seasoned staff members uneasy. Nurse Patricia Williams had worked the night shift for seventeen years, but something about this particular dawn felt different—heavier, more ominous than usual. She couldn't shake the feeling that someone was watching her as she made her rounds through the cardiac wing.

Detective Inspector Maria Bourazopoulou laced up her running shoes in the cramped locker room of Salisbury Police Station, her mind already racing through the case files that had been piling up on her desk. At thirty-four, she had earned a reputation as one of the most tenacious investigators in Wiltshire, partly due to her ability to think clearly during her early morning runs through the ancient streets of Salisbury. The rhythmic pounding of her feet against pavement had a way of organizing her thoughts, of revealing connections that others might miss.

But today would be different. Today would mark the beginning of a case that would haunt her for years to come.

The call came in at 6:47 AM, just as Maria was finishing her usual five-mile circuit around the cathedral. Her mobile buzzed insistently against her hip, the screen displaying the number she'd memorized long ago—dispatch.

"Bourazopoulou here," she answered, still breathing hard from her run.

"Ma'am, we've got a situation at St. Margaret's. You need to get down here immediately. It's... well, it's unlike anything we've seen before."

Maria's pulse quickened, though not from the exercise. In her twelve years on the force, she'd learned to read the subtle inflections in her colleagues' voices. This wasn't routine. This was something that would stick with them all.

Twenty minutes later, she stood in the doorway of a patient room on the third floor, staring at what could only be described as a scene from a fever dream. Nurse Patricia Williams lay unconscious on the hospital bed, her uniform stained with tears from what appeared to have been uncontrollable laughter. But it was her skin that made Maria's stomach turn—every inch of exposed flesh had been painted a garish shade of orange, applied with meticulous care and artistic precision.

"She's alive," said Dr. James Henley, the attending physician who'd discovered Patricia during morning rounds. "Physically unharmed, but completely traumatized. She keeps mumbling about someone tickling her, about not being able to breathe from laughing so hard."

Maria pulled on latex gloves and approached the bed carefully. Patricia's eyes were open but unfocused, staring at something only she could see. Orange paint covered her arms, face, and neck—anywhere the perpetrator could reach without removing her clothing. The application was too even, too deliberate to be random violence.

"Has she said anything coherent?" Maria asked, crouching beside the bed.

Dr. Henley shook his head. "Only fragments. Something about a woman named Betty, and..." He paused, looking uncomfortable. "She keeps repeating slurs. Horrible language about gay people. But Patricia's never spoken that way before—everyone here will tell you she's one of the most accepting people you could meet."

The pieces began forming a puzzle in Maria's mind, though the picture they created made little sense. She'd seen psychological torture before, but never anything quite like this. The orange paint suggested premeditation, planning. The tickling indicated a desire to cause distress without permanent physical harm. But the homophobic element added a layer of complexity that troubled her deeply.

"I'll need to speak with her as soon as she's able," Maria said, standing and surveying the room for any clues the perpetrator might have left behind. "Has anyone checked the security footage?"

"That's the strange thing," Dr. Henley replied. "The cameras on this floor malfunctioned between 3 AM and 5 AM. Complete blackout. Maintenance is looking into it, but they say it appears someone knew exactly which wires to cut."

Maria felt the familiar tingle of recognition that came with confronting a worthy adversary. This wasn't random—it was planned, executed with precision, and designed to send a message. But what message, and to whom?

As she examined the room more closely, Maria noticed something that the medical staff had missed. On the window sill, barely visible against the white paint, someone had left a small symbol drawn in the same orange paint used on Patricia. It looked like a crude flower, or perhaps a sun with irregular rays extending outward.

"Doctor, did Patricia mention anything about her personal life recently? Any conflicts, relationship issues, anything that might make her a target?"

Dr. Henley considered the question carefully. "Well, she did mention that her daughter came out to her a few months ago. Patricia was over the moon about it—said she was proud of her daughter's courage. She even started volunteering with some LGBTQ+ support groups in her spare time."

The connection crystallized in Maria's mind like ice forming on a window. This wasn't random violence—it was targeted specifically because of Patricia's support for her gay daughter. Someone had chosen her precisely because she represented acceptance and love in the face of hatred.

But who was Betty?

Over the next three hours, Maria interviewed every member of the hospital staff who'd been on duty during the night shift. None of them had seen anything unusual, heard any disturbances, or noticed strangers in the building. It was as if the perpetrator had materialized from thin air, committed her bizarre crime, and vanished just as mysteriously.

Patricia finally became coherent enough to speak around noon, though her account of the attack was fragmented and terrifying.

"She was already in my room when I came in to check on Mr. Henderson," Patricia whispered, her voice hoarse from hours of involuntary laughter. "Just standing there in the shadows like she belonged. I asked if she needed help, if she was lost, and she smiled at me. Such a cold smile."

"What did she look like?" Maria asked gently, her notebook ready.

"Average height, maybe mid-thirties. Brown hair, nothing distinctive about her appearance. But her eyes..." Patricia shuddered. "Her eyes were full of hate. She asked me if I knew what I was doing to society, supporting degenerates and perverts. I told her she was wrong, that love was love, and that's when she grabbed me."

Patricia's account of the attack itself was almost too bizarre to believe. Betty had produced a small bottle of what appeared to be chloroform, but instead of rendering Patricia unconscious, it had only made her weak and unable to resist. Then came the tickling—methodical, relentless, designed to cause maximum psychological distress while leaving no permanent physical damage.

"She kept talking while she did it," Patricia continued, tears streaming down her cheeks. "Saying horrible things about gay people, about how I was corrupting society by accepting my daughter. The painting came last, after I was too exhausted to fight back. She said I looked better in orange, that it was the color of warning signs."

Maria felt anger rising in her chest, but she forced herself to remain professional. "Patricia, did she mention her last name, or anything that might help us identify her?"

"Betty Morrison," Patricia said without hesitation. "She introduced herself like we were meeting at a tea party. Said I should remember her name because I'd be seeing her again."

The name meant nothing to Maria, but she made a mental note to run it through every database available. As she prepared to leave the hospital, her phone buzzed with another call from dispatch.

"Ma'am, we've got another one."

The second crime scene was located in a modest terraced house on Fisherton Street, just fifteen minutes from St. Margaret's Hospital. Maria arrived to find the familiar chaos of a fresh investigation—uniformed officers securing the perimeter, forensics teams preparing their equipment, and the inevitable cluster of curious neighbors gathering despite the afternoon drizzle that had begun to fall across Salisbury.

Sergeant Paul Hendricks met her at the front door, his usually composed demeanor betrayed by the tight lines around his eyes. In the eight years they'd worked together, Maria had learned to read Paul's expressions like a barometer for the severity of whatever awaited her inside. Today, that barometer was pointing toward storm conditions.

"Victim is Michael Chen, twenty-eight years old, works as a graphic designer from home," Paul began, consulting his notebook. "His partner, David Walsh, found him when he came back from a business trip about an hour ago. Same MO as the hospital—orange paint, evidence of prolonged tickling, and psychological trauma. But this one's worse, Maria. Much worse."

They climbed the narrow staircase to the second floor, where the smell of paint fumes mixed unpleasantly with something else—fear, perhaps, or the lingering presence of cruelty. The bedroom door stood open, revealing a scene that made Maria's professional composure waver for just a moment. Michael Chen sat on the edge of his bed, wrapped in a clean bathrobe that someone had draped around his shoulders, but his face and arms still bore the telltale orange staining. Unlike Patricia Williams, however, Michael was conscious and articulate, though his hands shook as he attempted to light a cigarette.

"Mr. Chen," Maria said gently, settling into a chair that Paul had positioned near the bed. "I'm Detective Inspector Bourazopoulou. I know this is difficult, but I need to ask you some questions about what happened here."

Michael looked up at her with eyes that seemed decades older than his twenty-eight years. The orange paint had been applied with the same meticulous care as at the hospital—every visible inch of skin covered, but no damage to clothing or personal belongings. It was a signature, Maria realized, a calling card that spoke to the perpetrator's need for recognition and control.

"She knew everything about me," Michael said, his voice barely above a whisper. "Things that aren't public, things that only David and I know about our relationship. She talked about our anniversary dinner last month, about the argument we had over adopting a dog, about my mother's reaction when I came out to her three years ago. How could she know all of that?"

The implications sent a chill through Maria that had nothing to do with the October weather. This wasn't opportunistic violence—it was stalking, research, planning that must have taken weeks or months to execute. Betty Morrison, if that was even her real name, had chosen her victims carefully and studied them with the dedication of a scholar.

"Did she introduce herself the same way as she did to Patricia Williams?" Maria asked, though she suspected she already knew the answer.

Michael nodded, taking a shaky drag from his cigarette. "Betty Morrison, like we were old friends meeting for coffee. She was already here when I woke up this morning, sitting in that chair you're in now, just watching me sleep. I thought I was dreaming at first, or maybe having a nightmare. But when I tried to move, I realized she'd tied my hands to the bedframe while I slept."

The violation was profound—not just the physical restraint, but the knowledge that someone had been in his most private space, watching him in his most vulnerable state. Maria had seen victims of home invasion before, and she recognized the particular type of trauma that came from having one's sanctuary transformed into a crime scene.

"The tickling went on for hours," Michael continued, his voice growing stronger as he spoke, as if telling the story was helping him process the experience. "She had tools—feathers, brushes, even an electric toothbrush. But it was the talking that was worst. The things she said about David and me, about gay people in general. She had this theory that homosexuality was a disease that could be cured through what she called 'corrective discomfort.'"

Maria exchanged glances with Paul, who was taking detailed notes. They'd both encountered hate crimes before, but this felt different—more organized, more ideologically driven than the usual drunken violence or opportunistic harassment that comprised most anti-LGBTQ+ incidents in their jurisdiction.

"Michael, did she mention anything about other people she planned to visit? Any indication that this was part of a larger plan?"

"She talked about cleaning up the neighborhood," Michael replied, stubbing out his cigarette with more force than necessary. "Said there were too many people like me and David corrupting the traditional values of Salisbury. She mentioned something about a list, about working her way through names she'd collected over the past year."

The word 'list' struck Maria like a physical blow. A serial offender with a predetermined set of targets was every detective's nightmare—it meant more victims, escalation, and the constant pressure of trying to predict the unpredictable. But it also meant patterns, and patterns could be analyzed, understood, and ultimately used to catch the perpetrator.

"Did she give you any indication of how she chose you specifically?" Maria pressed. "Anything that might help us understand her selection criteria?"

Michael was quiet for a long moment, staring at his paint-stained hands. When he finally spoke, his voice carried a weight that suggested he'd been wrestling with the same question since the attack ended.

"She knew about the pride flag we hung in our front window during Pride Month," he said slowly. "She knew about David's work with the youth LGBTQ+ center. She even knew that we'd been planning to get married next summer, though we've only told our closest friends and family. It's like she's been watching us, cataloging everything we do that might identify us as gay."

The methodical nature of the surveillance was becoming clear, and it painted a picture of someone with significant time, resources, and dedication to her cause. Maria made a mental note to have the tech team examine Michael and David's social media accounts, their online presence, and any digital footprints that might have provided Betty Morrison with her intelligence.

"There's something else," Michael added, hesitating as if he wasn't sure whether to continue. "She took pictures. Not during the attack itself, but afterward, when I was too exhausted to resist. She said they were for her collection, to document her work. She was very proud of the paint job—kept talking about it like it was art."

The revelation added another disturbing dimension to the crimes. Photography suggested trophy-taking behavior, a desire to relive the attacks or possibly to share them with others who might share her ideology. It also raised the possibility that Betty Morrison wasn't working alone, that she might be part of a larger group or network of like-minded individuals.

As Maria prepared to conclude the interview, David Walsh appeared in the doorway, still wearing his business suit from his interrupted trip. He was a tall man with kind eyes that were currently red with tears and exhaustion, and his first instinct was clearly to protect his partner rather than assist with the investigation.

"Has he told you everything you need?" David asked, moving to sit beside Michael on the bed and wrapping an arm around his shoulders. "He's been through enough for one day."

Maria nodded, recognizing the signs of a couple that had been together long enough to communicate without words. "Just one more question, if you don't mind. Michael, did Betty Morrison leave any kind of calling card or symbol behind? Anything that might be significant to her personally?"

Michael brightened slightly, as if remembering something important. "On the mirror in our bathroom—she drew something in the orange paint before she left. It looked like a flower, but wrong somehow. Twisted."

Paul was already moving toward the ensuite bathroom, and his sharp intake of breath confirmed what Maria had suspected. The same crude symbol from Patricia Williams' hospital room was there, painted on the mirror in orange strokes that were confident and practiced. Betty Morrison wanted them to know she was responsible, wanted them to understand that this was just the beginning.

As they prepared to leave the Chen-Walsh residence, Maria's mind was already working through the connections and implications. Two victims, both connected to the LGBTQ+ community through personal relationships or activism. Both attacks involving orange paint applied with artistic precision. Both victims forced to endure hours of psychological torture designed to humiliate and terrify rather than cause permanent physical harm. And both left with the same symbol, the same signature that proclaimed Betty Morrison's twisted brand of ideological warfare.

The afternoon was darkening into evening by the time Maria returned to Salisbury Police Station, her notebook filled with details that painted an increasingly disturbing picture of their perpetrator. Betty Morrison was organized, patient, and driven by a hatred so profound that it had motivated her to develop an entirely new form of hate crime—one that maximized psychological impact while minimizing legal consequences.

**Chapter 2: The Orange Canvas**

Maria's desk at Salisbury Police Station had become a sprawling canvas of crime scene photographs, witness statements, and forensic reports that seemed to multiply with each passing hour. The fluorescent lights overhead cast harsh shadows across the images of orange-painted skin, creating an almost surreal gallery that would have been artistic if not for the underlying violence it represented. She had been staring at the same photograph for ten minutes—a close-up of the crude flower symbol left at both crime scenes—when Detective Constable Sarah Lynch knocked on her office door frame.

Sarah was twenty-six years old and relatively new to the detective division, but she possessed an analytical mind that complemented Maria's more intuitive approach to investigation. Her background in digital forensics had already proven invaluable in several recent cases, and Maria had specifically requested her assistance with what was rapidly becoming known around the station as the Orange Paint Case. The younger detective carried a steaming cup of coffee in one hand and a thick manila folder in the other, her expression suggesting she had discovered something significant.

"I've been running searches on Betty Morrison all afternoon," Sarah began, settling into the chair across from Maria's desk and opening her folder with the careful precision of someone who had spent hours organizing information. "The name appears in seventeen different databases across the UK, but none of the individuals match our perpetrator's description or demographic profile. Three of them are deceased, eight are over sixty years old, four are currently incarcerated, and two have solid alibis for both attack timeframes. I'm starting to think Betty Morrison might not be her real name."

Maria looked up from the photograph, unsurprised by Sarah's findings but disappointed nonetheless. Experienced criminals often used aliases, particularly when their crimes were ideologically motivated and planned well in advance. The fact that Betty Morrison had introduced herself so formally to both victims suggested either supreme confidence in her ability to evade capture or a deliberate attempt to mislead the investigation from the very beginning.

"What about the orange paint itself?" Maria asked, leaning back in her chair and rubbing her temples where a headache had been building for the past two hours. "Have forensics been able to tell us anything about the brand, the composition, where it might have been purchased?"

Sarah's expression brightened slightly as she flipped through several pages in her folder, clearly pleased to have some concrete information to share. "That's where we might have caught a break. The paint is a specialized theatrical makeup called 'Sunset Orange' manufactured by a company called Dramatic Arts Supply in London. It's not the kind of thing you'd find at your average hardware store or pharmacy. According to the manufacturer, it's primarily sold to theater companies, film studios, and specialty costume shops. They've only had twelve orders for this specific color in the past six months, and most of those were bulk purchases by established entertainment companies."

The specificity of the paint choice struck Maria as significant, another indication that Betty Morrison's crimes were carefully planned rather than impulsive acts of violence. The selection of theatrical makeup also suggested someone with knowledge of performance arts, costume design, or possibly even experience in theater production. It was the kind of detail that could narrow their search parameters considerably, assuming they could track down the specific purchase records and connect them to their perpetrator.

"I want you to contact every retailer that sells this paint within a hundred-mile radius of Salisbury," Maria instructed, making notes on a legal pad that was already covered with her handwriting from earlier in the day. "Get purchase records, security camera footage if it's still available, and descriptions of any customers who bought this specific color in the past six months. Also, reach out to local theater groups, costume rental companies, and art schools. Someone who knows about theatrical makeup might be involved in those communities."

Sarah nodded, scribbling additional notes in her own notebook before continuing with her report. "There's something else that might be relevant. I've been analyzing the social media presence of both victims, looking for common connections or shared online activities that might have brought them to our perpetrator's attention. Patricia Williams joined a Facebook group called 'Supportive Parents of LGBTQ+ Children' three months ago, right around the time her daughter came out. She's been quite active in the group, sharing articles about acceptance and offering encouragement to other parents who are struggling with their children's sexual orientation."

The online component added another layer to Betty Morrison's surveillance capabilities, and it suggested she was technologically sophisticated enough to monitor social media for potential targets. Maria had seen similar patterns in stalking cases, where perpetrators used online platforms to gather intelligence about their victims' daily routines, relationships, and vulnerabilities. The fact that Patricia Williams had been targeted so soon after joining a support group indicated that Betty Morrison was actively monitoring LGBTQ+ related online communities.

"What about Michael Chen and David Walsh?" Maria asked, though she suspected she already knew what Sarah had discovered during her digital investigation.

"Even more extensive online presence," Sarah replied, pulling out several printed screenshots from social media profiles. "David Walsh runs a blog called 'Love is Love in Salisbury' where he writes about LGBTQ+ issues in our community. He's been documenting their relationship for almost two years, including photos of their home, details about their daily routines, and their involvement with local pride events. Michael Chen is less active online, but he's tagged in most of David's posts and photos. Anyone following the blog would have a comprehensive understanding of their lives, their schedules, and their relationship dynamics."

The extent of the victims' online exposure was troubling, though Maria recognized that she couldn't fault them for living openly and celebrating their relationships. The problem wasn't their visibility—it was Betty Morrison's decision to use that visibility as a targeting mechanism for hate crimes. Still, understanding how the perpetrator selected her victims provided valuable insight into her methodology and might help predict future attacks.

Maria's contemplation was interrupted by a sharp knock on her office door, followed immediately by the appearance of Chief Inspector Robert Hawthorne. Hawthorne was a career policeman in his late fifties, known throughout the station for his direct communication style and his particular concern for crimes that might attract media attention or public controversy. His presence in Maria's office, combined with the grim expression on his weathered face, suggested that the Orange Paint Case had already attracted the kind of attention that made senior administrators nervous.

"I've just gotten off the phone with the Chief Constable, and there's concern that we might be dealing with something more organized than individual hate crimes. The Home Office has been monitoring online chatter in extremist communities, and there are indications that anti-LGBTQ+ groups have been discussing new tactics for what they call 'corrective intervention' without crossing the line into serious criminal charges."

The implications of organized hate group involvement sent a chill through Maria that had nothing to do with the October weather outside her office windows. Individual criminals, no matter how dedicated or methodical, operated within predictable parameters and could usually be caught through traditional investigative techniques.
